column4: Donkeys used for transport of belongings
not all year round – usually 3 in a district per tribe & only more when it becomes too dirty or there is an epidemic

vary in size from village of 7-8 huts to 50-60 (Hinde & Hinde 1901: 93); Fosbrooke (1948: 43) says village usually 4-5 families which probably not over 80 people; The warrior's village is from 50-100 men + the women (Forde 1948: 297)
warrior’s village where warriors live with mistresses & mothers
hedge of thorns around village site
all the huts joined in forming the circle so a curving rectangle
plastered with the cow dung that cracks in the sun
in the rainy season the roof is covered with skins

certain tribes of Masai have claim to certain territory & even if they leave their villages, others can stay in it but it belongs to the original builders (Hinde & Hinde 1901: 98); unclear whether tribal property or individual (Hinde & Hinde 1901: 104); land owned by substribe (Huntingford 1953: 108)
?; claimed by a clan (water wells) where other clans present
(-); Shields & spears marked with owner’s age group & subdistrict; [HRAF OCM 422]
Clothing & weapons only are destroyed or sold
the chief willing everything to his chosen heir in front of the elders (Hinde & Hinde 1901: 24-25); may leave a part of property to anyone. The rest must go to sons (Fox 1901: 460)
Smiths - one clan in particular, but each clan has its smiths
subjugated tribe Elgunoni are the iron workers (Hinde & Hinde 1901: 86)
trade for vegetable food with Kikuyu [The reference (Fosbrooke 1948: 443) seems incorrect]
all vegetable food is traded for
“protectors” of sheep andcattle paid in beer or snuff
a poor man looks after brothers-in-law’s cattle & gets feed & receives goats
smiths warriors have own village [HRAF OCM 564]
(-); any child can attach himself to member of royal clan & must be accepted by family
The two men cut their arms, dip beef in the blood & eat it; trade red beads
shamans all come from same family of a certain clan
Father-in-law may be generous & give cattle but this not required
after the bride price is paid they are married
daughters of smiths cannot marry other men & smiths have own language
men of importance sit on wooden stool (Hinde & Hinde 1901: 97); only wealthy men may wear arm bracelet of buffalo horn (Hollis 1905: 284); smiths & Masai have different rights (Leakey 1930: 209)
the headman of the village lives in a house larger than the rest, in the middle of the circle
regular people thrown to the hyenas but medicine men & rich men are buried in a hole & covered with stones
inside crude log structures or thrown into the bush
Batian the chief chosen from royal family
for sub-chief choose man with cattle & family
a secret service that spies around the country & reports all doings to the chief
when chief sends a messenger, sends his club along to verify message
He is the chief medicine man
The royal family has a secret medicine that the chief takes once or twice a year in order to see into the future. Before battle also.
Sub-chief wears a special robe & earrings (Hollis 1905 300); big chief has iron club (Hollis 1905: 329)
chiefly line descendant of Black god – there being a White god, Blue god & Red god
royal family only is buried & huge pile of stones erected over the site
influential people become snakes & they are fed & honored
chief receives around half of raid spoils
?; in war the chief of the warriors is protected
formal ceremony, suckle each others babies
The Dorrobo and Elgunonu work for the Masai and obey orders; though they do get paid – but they are infereior and not allowed to intermarry with Masai.
drinks blood & says that if he has lied he shall die
after murder if victims brothers do not avenge death then elders make peace between murderer and brothers
claimant chooses a group of elders to judge his case
accuser might have to use same ordeal as accused
man swears that if he lies may god kill him
so organized – probably upheld by elders
murderer has to pay 49 bullocks – but does not say to whom
if a man steals a cow all his property is then confiscated by the victim – punishment differs according to article stolen
for 3rd theft man crippled by victim
(-); “masai prisoners in Nairobi Gaol appear to be particularly susceptible to pulmonary infections”
instead of confiscating whole herd of murderers, victim’s brother’s might settle for heavy fine
oaths taken to show veracity – if lies then the man will lose all his luck & die
an enemy boy is captured & sent with a message back to his tribe as a warning of the coming attack
chief of territorial age set governs military matters
The older experts who have say over the younger – warriors divided into age sets
simply a life stage which must serve for 30 years before can marry
booty belongs to tribe. Warriors not allowed to own property, supported by tribe
use of poison below them, must warn enemy, equal to combat
shields painted in order to identify company
Before the Kudu became extinct its horns were used as trumpers for a call signal in war
a man who has killed many enemy can wear a special armband
bravest  get bigger division of booty
warriors get to paint mark of bravery on their shields (Hollis 1905: 291); high status achieved by killing (Fosbrooke 1948:15)
Masai now composed of many former enemies who have been absorbed
The Masai return in the form of snakes & snakes are well treated & invoked
Ngal – sometimes he is personified but is not constant & equals rain & permeates every natural things
annihilation after death unless have children (Hinde & Hinde 1901: 99); but then only the important men are reincarnated as the guardian snakes (Hinde & Hinde 1901: 102)
pour milk & honey wine on the ground before war, other times pour blood
sacrifice a goat under the Orretete tree
certainly there is private worship but no mention of any idols, altars or shrines
cure, insure fidelity in wives etc. for fee
the next step after private practice – to bring rain, help war etc.
Then asked to superintent circumcision rites
laibon provides charms for local fertility ceremonies & rain ceremonies
The Laibon’s major job is to give the warriors prayers before a raid.
?; share of booty given to laibon who considered as god
statues of Ngal in wood or ivory
they are paid for their services – chief laibon receives gifts of cattle etc. Nobody really works however [HRAF OCM 756]
(-); very few Masai women make any pottery
some women know how to make pots. Others have to buy from the Swahili.
carve pipe bowls made out of hard wood (Hinde & Hinde 1901: 90); Ngal (Koenig 1956: 94)
hearth[?] stones & cooking pot & pile of twigs covered with a skin (Hinde & Hinde 1901: 92); bed = a skin stretched over poles
engraving; brass ring with design embelished on it; [HRAF OCM 306, 325 - no entry]
as opposed to the Wonika who rest every 4 days
(+); each village has a qualified midwife; special name for midwife but no mention of payment (Huntingford 1953: 115)
take out splinters of bone & bring the edges of the broken bone together; If a rib is broken or shattered it is removed & a sheep’s rib put in its place.
